awd_titl_txt: Acquistion of a SQUID Magnetometer System for Magnetic      Characterization of Novel Materials
awd_abstract_narration: 9601825  Tsui    A superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID)  magnetometer will be acquired by the University of North Carolina  at Chapel Hill. The magnetometer will be used to study the static  and dynamic response of metallic and oxide thin films and  superlattices. Four types of materials will be studies: metallic  thin films and superlattices, high temperature superconducting  films, thin films of metallic glasses, and nanostructures made by  scanning probe microscopy techniques. The SQUID will be used to  investigate magnetic phases, magnetic coupling and  magnetotransport  in metallic superlattices, effects of oxygen  content in high temperature superconductors, electronic states  and ordering in metallic glasses, and spin fluctuations and  electron-electron interactions in nanostructures.  %%%  This research will help to elucidate the role of morphology and  dimensionality on the material properties and to understand the  nature of the magnetic and electronic interactions in these  materials. Placement of the SQUID magnetometer in the Research  Triangle Park area will enhance the local research  infrastructure.  ***
